Award.AwardTitle: EAGER/Cybermanufacturing: Smart Manufacturing Platform for Tissue Engineering

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Organ failure and tissue damage are major health problems. The current therapy of organ transplantation is inadequate because of the shortage of available donor organs, resulting in long waiting times. A promising alternative is tissue engineering, which seeks to create functional tissues to replace or repair damaged tissues using biomaterial-substitutes (scaffolds). Scaffolds have stringent design requirements, such a three-dimensional (3D) internal-porous structure, patient-specific geometry, and appropriate materials and mechanical properties to encourage the growth of functional living tissues. Current scaffold manufacturing methods typically adopt a trial-and-error approach, which does not consider comprehensive interactions among design, material and process and results in scaffolds with unpredictable properties. The goal of this EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project is to develop an intelligent system to guide the optimization of shape, materials and process parameters, resulting in a smart decision matrix for designing and manufacturing 3D scaffolds.

The objective of this project is to research an SOA (Service Oriented Architecture) based integrated technical and social networking platform that enables effective human-human collaboration and communication among the domains of product (3D porous scaffold), process (Fused Deposition Modelling-FDM) and material (thermoplastic polycaprolactone-PCL). This smart platform, enabled by semantic web technology and social network analysis, embeds the capability of intelligent configurations of design and manufacturing solutions; therefore promoting information and knowledge reuse and cost reduction. Although the focus of this work is on porous PCL scaffolds using the FDM process, the knowledge-driven, smart platform can be extended to other biomanufacturing methods.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major project goal was to develop a new intelligent information platform which will guide the decision making process for manufacturing three dimensional biomaterial scaffolds as well as for other non-biological applications. We developed an integrated model that combines product, process, and materials information models. An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV), a test bed capable of generating high-throughput data, was used to validate the predictive information models. The predictive models were demonstrated to communicate effectively with the sPLM (Smart Product Lifecycle Management) platform and making accurate decisions from its both physical and data analytics models. A modified version of this computational platform was awarded in the New York GENIUS 2.0 International competition for its unique enterprise-level capabilities and for its data-driven decision-making features. In a parallel manner, extrusion based 3D printing or Fused Deposition Modeling (FDM) were carried out using commonly used thermoplastics and hydrogel-based bioinks. Since current printing technology was found to be inadequate to provide large amount of data that can be fed into the information models, this aspect of the project focused on the design and development of new bioprinting hardware that would allow researchers to establish the relationships between biomaterial properties and printing conditions. Work with commonly used biocompatible thermoplastics and hydrogels biomaterials will enable the application of predictive information models to the domain of bioprinting. In summary, this work developed the concepts and validation for the model-based systems coordination and collaboration for complex physical systems that could be easily integrated in any similar data-driven system environment including bioprinting processing. This work will benefit the human activities and decision-making processes wherever use of both physical and data analytics models is necessary.


Last Modified: 10/14/2018
Modified by: Pranav Soman

In a parallel manner, extrusion based 3D printing or Fused Deposition Modeling (FDM) were carried out using commonly used thermoplastics and hydrogel-based bioinks. Since current printing technology was found to be inadequate to provide large amount of data that can be fed into the information models, this aspect of the project focused on the design and development of new bioprinting hardware that would allow researchers to establish the relationships between biomaterial properties and printing conditions. Work with commonly used biocompatible thermoplastics and hydrogels biomaterials will enable the application of predictive information models to the domain of bioprinting.
